column4: i have downloaded ubuntu-desktop it installs fine but after the loading screen goes to a black screen, same from livecd - this is an optiplex 745 that has installed debian and linuxmint just fine - any ideas? I've been trying to get it going for 3 days, i'm a little lost as to why debian boots fine, as does linuxmint (which is based on ubuntu? or debian at least)
note that if i install ubuntu-server, it loads fine, it's obviously an issue with gnome or x
It's probably some X option that video card doesn't like -- reboot the CD again and check the list of boot options, theres one for a 'safe video mode', though I dont recall what it is.
- thanks i'll try that
np mate, let us know how it goes.
use safe video mode produces an interesting result, it loads to a very artifact infested screen, gets a busy cursor, and then goes completely white - with the cursor still visible and active
Wow.  What kinda system again?
however while I was typing that, it looks like xserver restarted and i'm on the desktop now - if I install how do I enable whatever this did?
an optiplex 745, intel 975G chipset/onboard video if i'm not mistaken, I've nveer had an issue with it under windows or any other linux distro before
I *think* whatever boot options you use on the cd are propogated to the installation.  I remember having to use a certain flag for a laptop and the issue never occured in the installed copy.
Pretty recent chipset, this is Hardy?
correct
8.04, downloaded and burned yesterday
Wierd.  I've never used it on that chipset, I wonder if it's a chipset-specific bug.
well, the last time I burned it was yesterday, I thought maybe something was wrong with the CD
I've googled and found other people reporting the issue as far back as the GX260 on gutsy gibbon, but it looks like anytime someone fixes it they never say how...
Anyway, whatever flag you booted with could be appended to the /boot/grub/menu.lst file to produce the same result, theoretically.  I think the installation LiveCD is the same kernel.
I'm going to try enabling the safe video mode and installing, I'll report back about how ti goes =P
For the record, I think safe video mode uses the Xorg "vesa" driver instead of autodetecting nvidia, nv, radeon, intel, etc.  I'm guessing the chipset would autodetect intel and try that.

honestly, this is for a little 'rack' of 12 optiplex's, I wanted to try something besides debian, I like having a gui environment instead of just staring at terminals when i play with them, but once they're set up I really just remote desktop in with vnc
Then vesa is fine ;).  I can't say I agree with you though, I usually roll out ubuntu-server on .. uh.. servers :)
I'm just not totally comfortable with my terminal skills yet, I use the terminal alot, but for some things I'm just not "there" yet
